Find $\sin 20^\circ \sin 40^\circ \sin 60^\circ \sin 80^\circ \sin 100^\circ \sin 120^\circ \sin 140^\circ \sin 160^\circ.$
inference:
Using the product-to-sum formula, we have

$$\begin{split} \sin 20^\circ \sin 40^\circ \sin 60^\circ \sin 80^\circ \sin 100^\circ \sin 120^\circ \sin 140^\circ \sin 160^\circ &= \frac{1}{2} \left[ \cos 20^\circ - \cos 60^\circ \right] \left[ \cos 40^\circ - \cos 80^\circ \right] \\\ & \qquad \left[ \cos 60^\circ - \cos 120^\circ \right] \left[ \cos 80^\circ - \cos 140^\circ \right] \\\ & \qquad \left[ \cos 100^\circ - \cos 160^\circ \right] \\\ &= \frac{1}{2} \left[ \cos 20^\circ - \cos 60^\circ \right] \left[ \cos 40^\circ - \cos 80^\circ \right] \\\ & \qquad \left[ \cos 60^\circ - \cos 120^\circ \right] \left[ \cos 80^\circ - \cos 140^\circ \right] \\\ & \qquad \left[ \cos 100^\circ + \cos 160^\circ \right] \\\ &= \frac{1}{2} \left[ \cos 20^\circ - \cos 60^\circ \right] \left[ \cos 40^\circ - \cos 80^\circ \right] \\\ & \qquad \left[ \cos 60^\circ - \cos 120^\circ \right] \left[ \cos 80^\circ + \cos 140^\circ \right] \\\ & \qquad \left[ \cos 100^\circ + \cos 160^\circ \right] \\\ &= \frac{1}{2} \left[ \cos 20^\circ - \cos 60^\circ \right] \left[ \cos 40^\circ + \cos 80^\circ \right] \\\ & \qquad \left[ \cos 60^\circ - \cos 120^\circ \right] \left[ \cos 80^\circ + \cos 140^\circ \right] \\\ & \qquad \left[ \cos 100^\circ + \cos 160^\circ \right] \\\ &= \frac{1}{2} \left[ \cos 20^\circ + \cos 60^\circ \right] \left[ \cos 40^\circ + \cos 80^\circ \right] \\\ & \qquad \left[ \cos 60^\circ - \cos 120^\circ \right] \left[ \cos 80^\circ + \cos 140^\circ \right] \\\ & \qquad \left[ \cos 100^\circ + \cos 160^\circ \right] \\\ &= \frac{1}{2} \left[ \cos 20^\circ + \cos 60^\circ \right] \left[ \cos 40^\circ + \cos 80^\circ \right] \\\ & \qquad \left[ \cos 60^\circ + \cos 120^\circ \right] \left[ \cos 80^\circ + \cos 140^\circ \right] \\\ & \qquad \left[ \cos 100^\circ + \cos 160^\circ \right] \\\ &= \frac{1}{2} \left[ \cos 20^\circ + \cos 60^\circ \right] \left[ \cos 40^\circ + \cos 80^\circ \right] \\\ & \qquad \left[ \cos 60^\circ + \cos 120^\circ \right] \left[ \cos 80^\circ - \cos 140^\circ \right] \\\ & \qquad \left[ \cos 100^\circ + \cos 160^\circ \right] \\\ &= \frac{1}{2} \left[ \cos 20^\circ + \cos 60^\circ \right] \left[ \cos 40^\circ - \cos 80^\circ \right] \\\ & \qquad \left[ \cos 60^\circ +
ground_truth:
First, we know $\sin 60^\circ = \sin 120^\circ = \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2},$ so
\begin{align*}
&\sin 20^\circ \sin 40^\circ \sin 60^\circ \sin 80^\circ \sin 100^\circ \sin 120^\circ \sin 140^\circ \sin 160^\circ \\
&= \frac{3}{4} \sin 20^\circ \sin 40^\circ \sin 80^\circ \sin 100^\circ \sin 140^\circ \sin 160^\circ.
\end{align*}We can then write $\sin 80^\circ = \sin 100^\circ = \cos 10^\circ,$ $\sin 140^\circ = \sin 40^\circ,$ $\sin 160^\circ = \sin 20^\circ,$ so
\begin{align*}
\frac{3}{4} \sin 20^\circ \sin 40^\circ \sin 80^\circ \sin 100^\circ \sin 140^\circ \sin 160^\circ &= \frac{3}{4} \cos^2 10^\circ \sin^2 20^\circ \sin^2 40^\circ \\
&= \frac{3}{4} (\cos 10^\circ \sin 20^\circ \sin 40^\circ)^2.
\end{align*}By product-to-sum,
\begin{align*}
\cos 10^\circ \sin 20^\circ \sin 40^\circ &= \cos 10^\circ \cdot \frac{1}{2} (\cos 20^\circ - \cos 60^\circ) \\
&= \frac{1}{2} \cos 10^\circ \left( \cos 20^\circ - \frac{1}{2} \right) \\
&= \frac{1}{2} \cos 10^\circ \cos 20^\circ - \frac{1}{4} \cos 10^\circ \\
&= \frac{1}{4} (\cos 30^\circ + \cos 10^\circ) - \frac{1}{4} \cos 10^\circ \\
&= \frac{1}{4} \cos 30^\circ \\
&= \frac{\sqrt{3}}{8}.
\end{align*}Therefore, the expression is equal to $\frac{3}{4} \left( \frac{\sqrt{3}}{8} \right)^2 = \boxed{\frac{9}{256}}.$

ground_truth:
First, we know $\sin 60^\circ = \sin 120^\circ = \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2},$ so
\begin{align*}
&\sin 20^\circ \sin 40^\circ \sin 60^\circ \sin 80^\circ \sin 100^\circ \sin 120^\circ \sin 140^\circ \sin 160^\circ \\
&= \frac{3}{4} \sin 20^\circ \sin 40^\circ \sin 80^\circ \sin 100^\circ \sin 140^\circ \sin 160^\circ.
\end{align*}We can then write $\sin 80^\circ = \sin 100^\circ = \cos 10^\circ,$ $\sin 140^\circ = \sin 40^\circ,$ $\sin 160^\circ = \sin 20^\circ,$ so
\begin{align*}
\frac{3}{4} \sin 20^\circ \sin 40^\circ \sin 80^\circ \sin 100^\circ \sin 140^\circ \sin 160^\circ &= \frac{3}{4} \cos^2 10^\circ \sin^2 20^\circ \sin^2 40^\circ \\
&= \frac{3}{4} (\cos 10^\circ \sin 20^\circ \sin 40^\circ)^2.
\end{align*}By product-to-sum,
\begin{align*}
\cos 10^\circ \sin 20^\circ \sin 40^\circ &= \cos 10^\circ \cdot \frac{1}{2} (\cos 20^\circ - \cos 60^\circ) \\
&= \frac{1}{2} \cos 10^\circ \left( \cos 20^\circ - \frac{1}{2} \right) \\
&= \frac{1}{2} \cos 10^\circ \cos 20^\circ - \frac{1}{4} \cos 10^\circ \\
&= \frac{1}{4} (\cos 30^\circ + \cos 10^\circ) - \frac{1}{4} \cos 10^\circ \\
&= \frac{1}{4} \cos 30^\circ \\
&= \frac{\sqrt{3}}{8}.
\end{align*}Therefore, the expression is equal to $\frac{3}{4} \left( \frac{\sqrt{3}}{8} \right)^2 = \boxed{\frac{9}{256}}.$
